data.title: Which console had the better library BEFORE Sonic 1's release? Genesis or Turbografx-16? (Lists inside)
data.meta_description: Before Sonic took off the Genesis was not super hot in the US, and it's competition, released around the same time, was Nec and their Turbografx-16...
data.text:
Before Sonic took off the Genesis was not super hot in the US, and it's competition, released around the same time, was Nec and their Turbografx-16.

However the Genesis pulled ahead by a good amount even before Sonic. Letting Sega grab the vacuum that was the teenager/young adult demographic for themselves and setting the stage for it's bounce. Leading it to have great third party support later.

But NEC clearly had the better game line up and screens in mags. It's crazy how pre Sonic Sega some how beat the TG16 early library.

Here are some examples:

TG16 early pre Sonic US lineup:

Alien Crush

Blazing Lasers

Keith Courage

China Warrior

Dungeon Explorer

R-type

Legendary Axe 1 and 2

Monster Lair (Wonder Boy III enhanced remake)

Jack Nick's Turbo Golf

Klax

Space Harrier

JJ and Jeff

Bonks Adventure

Neutopia

YS book 1+2

Cyber Core

Bloody Wolf

Double Dungeons

Splatter House

Bravoman

Tiger Road

Devil's Crush

Ninja Spirit

Dragon's Curse

Last Alert

Valis II

Bomberman

Aero Blasters

Super Star Soldier

Genesis pre Sonic US lineup:

Altered Beast

Ms Pacman

Super Thunder Blade

Ghouls n ghosts

Thunder Force II

Super Hang-on

Burning Force

Revenge of Shinobi

Golden Axe

Phantasy Star II

Herzog Zwei

After Burner II

Super Hydlide

Columns

Atomic Robokid

Michael Jackson's moon walker

Inspector X

Strider

Thunder Force III

Castle of illusion mickey mouse

Cyberball.

As you can witness, The Genesis got torn to shreds, with such fun and varied games that have in most cases, greater polish.

I am still baffled that even before Sonic, Sega managed to stay around 1 million units in front of NEC and the Turbo.

Ms pacman was the best selling Genesis game next to Altered Beast before Sonic, maybe that brought in older casuals or was a game parents shared with kids. But that would only explain some of the gap.

Which console do you think had the best pre-Sonic library (1989-early 91) in the US?

Imo, Sega was just demolished. It's not even fare. Poor NEC, such injustice in the US market.

Even if you knew nothing about either line up, a quick "genesis best games" and "turbo grafx 16 games" searches would tell you all you need to know. The majority of the best tg16 games when you search came out in the 80's, majority of the best genesis games came out in the early/mid 90's.

Eh, the Turbo CDs most popular games were in the 90's so I guess it depends on if you combine both or separate hucard games.

Turbo if you ask me. Few really great Genesis games are from the 80s.

Genesis/Mega Drive is really weird, it released in 88 but that's not ingrained into everyone's mind, most people will tell you that the console launched around the same time as SFC/SNES.

i got mine in 1989.

I love both of these libraries but I played much more Revenge of Shinobi, Castle of Illusion, Strider and (especially) Ghouls n Ghosts at the time.

Why ask the question if your entire angle seems like you're trying to prove that the Genesis library was inferior? Both libraries had a lot to offer and even early on had bona fide classics.

Sega had a very aggressive marketing campaign. It was everywhere and all of my friends knew about it. The TG16 was like the Sega Master System of the 16-bit era awareness-wise (not software-wise).

Marketing and retail distribution was more important than you perhaps realize. They didn't have the internet and YouTube videos back then and no one would have any idea what games were available, if they were any good, or even where to get them.

My experience at that time was most Genesis owners bought the system for sports games which you entirely ignored.

Marketing and retail distribution was more important than you perhaps realize. They didn't have the internet and YouTube videos back then and no one would have any idea what games were available, if they were any good, or even where to get them.

My experience at that time was most Genesis owners bought the system for sports games which you entirely ignored.

Which were barely a thing pre Sonic. And both systems had them near even when they did. Also TG16 had near equal coverage.

The list of Genesis games in the OP is woefully incomplete.

Wikipedia lists 85 Genesis games that precede Sonic's North American release: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Sega_Genesis_games

while the OP only lists about 20. Why?

Why aren't you asking me why I didn't list "every" TG16 game too? Why only Sega?

I said in the OP "some examples" not "every game" lol. I typed this thread on a phone. Tough enough to get the current lists out.lol.

(Also wiki isn't a good source there's missing games for both )

I had a TG16 and immediately regretted it when the Genesis launched.

In the US at least I thought it was no contest and much preferred the console and games from Sega. The Genesis was really a step forward graphically when it launched.

Hell for a 1988 console it was able to compete the snes for a while and got support up to what, 1996-1997? I rembember lots of people thought the genesis was new when Sonic came out in 1991. Goes to show it was still 'fresh' graphically.

A console full of nice experiments too from many developers.

Hell for a 1988 console it was able to compete the snes for a while and got support up to what, 1996-1997? I rembember lots of people thought the genesis was new when Sonic came out in 1991. Goes to show it was still 'fresh' but graphically.

A console full of nice experiments too from many developers.

I am not sure if it was really a perfect port but stuff like Altered Beast and Ghouls and Ghosts looked arcade perfect to me when I first see it.

The TG16 could not compete with that. At least I didn't think so as a kid.

The double-spacing of the lists in the OP bothers me. As does the exclusion of Bonanza Bros, which I'd legitimately take over anything named here.

Bonanza Bros fans unite.

It's one of those games that superficially looks like shit? Or like...you can just LOOK at it and tell that it isn't any fun.

But it is a lot of fucking fun. Man, that's an IP Sega really needs to revisit.

I am not sure if it was really a perfect port but stuff like Altered Beast and Ghouls and Ghosts looked arcade perfect to me when I first see it.

The TG16 could not compete with that. At least I didn't think so as a kid.

Splatterhouse and Galaga 88/90 are great, and we're very good conversions for the time.

Hell for a 1988 console it was able to compete the snes for a while and got support up to what, 1996-1997? I rembember lots of people thought the genesis was new when Sonic came out in 1991. Goes to show it was still 'fresh' graphically.

A console full of nice experiments too from many developers.

The one-two punch of Sega of America's 1991 marketing campaign and the release of Sonic the Hedgehog is a very particular inflection point in history that I think back to fairly often. It was almost like a "stealth relaunch" of the Genesis, which up until then wasn't much more than a curiosity with extremely little mindshare in the general public. They just went all out on multiple fronts at the same time: blockbuster mascot platformer, $50 price cut, and over-the-top ad campaign all during the tail end of '91.

Like I know I wasn't the only one out of my peers who tried out both Sonic and Mario World on public demo kiosks at about the same time, and did a double-take when I'd look at their respective systems' software catalogs and think "wait, the Sega already has 100 games?"

This is an extremely slanted OP. You might mention the games but I don't know if you remember living through it, but it was actually kind of hard to find Genesis games for a long while much less Tg-16 games... My local KB Toys and I think Service Merchandise were only places that might get Sega games but they were always limited even after Sonic. Stupid Nintendo nonsense

Also anyone who unironically mentions 'JJ and Jeff' as a game worth playing.... Ugh. Bad memories

Separately, I am still sad I never picked up more Master System games before the big bubble. It's what it is though.
